@graph.involvedParties: Brooke Group Ltd. v. Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp.
@graph.reasoning: The jury, of course, was so instructed, see n. 2, supra, and no one questions that proposition here.
For that reason, predatory price cutting is not unlawful unless the predator has a reasonable prospect of recouping his investment from supracompetitive profits.

@graph.caseNumber: Atlantic Richfield Co. v. USA Petroleum Co.
@graph.involvedParties: Atlantic Richfield Co. v. USA Petroleum Co.
@graph.reasoning: In Atlantic Richfield Co. v. USA Petroleum Co., 495 U. S. 328,339-340 (1990), for example, we noted that low prices benefit consumers "so long as they are above predatory levels."

@graph.caseNumber: Cargill, Inc. v. Monfort of Colorado, Inc.
@graph.involvedParties: Cargill, Inc. v. Monfort of Colorado, Inc.
@graph.reasoning: In Cargill, Inc. v. Monfort of Colorado, Inc., 479 U. S. 104, 118 (1986), we recognized that price cutting of a predatory nature is "inimical" to competition, and limited our approving comments to pricing that is "above some measure of incremental costs."
